name: TheAtlantic
text: If Trump tries to steal the election, people will surely protest. But stopping a coup requires more strategy, @JudithShulevitz writes. https://t.co/EazqBFOLSf

name: TheAtlantic
text: There's plenty that's going wrong for Trump. Here are four things his campaign is doing now to close the gap with Joe Biden, @PeterAtlantic reports. https://t.co/pKG9xuXA4h

name: TheAtlantic
text: Who knew in this partisan age that politicians could hold their own side to account? @helenlewis explains: https://t.co/88H7zF8lfB

name: TheAtlantic
text: Early voting has long been the norm for Americans overseas. This year, they're poised to turn out in record numbers, reports @YasmeenSerhan: https://t.co/ff9Qfz3r5q

name: TheAtlantic
text:
"The bodies of incarcerated people are counted in the way we build our political infrastructure, but their voices are not," writes @ClintSmithIII:
https://t.co/G7x2gXMgKU

name: TheAtlantic
text: As thousands die on his watch, the president is severing any lingering ties to scientific reality. @jameshamblin on the ominous implications: https://t.co/Pbur1rAATz

name: TheAtlantic
text: He’s assailed democratic norms, but the president is lauded in parts of Asia for his hawkishness toward China, @TMcLaughlin3 explains: https://t.co/bwpnrtgBdA

name: TheAtlantic
text: "Ponyo." "Julie & Julia." "Unstoppable." "Addams Family Values." Everyone has their own list of "comfort movies," but @davidlsims turns to these 25 genre-spanning films again and again: https://t.co/UPxvEdjKYa

name: TheAtlantic
text: "The Supreme Court has transformed constitutional provisions for fighting racial segregation into instruments that preserve it," @LeahLitman writes: https://t.co/7EeWhd9Tt2

name: TheAtlantic
text: Books by Ocean Vuong, Elizabeth Acevedo, Ben Lerner, and more bring poetic voice to works written in prose in this week's #TheAtlanticBooksBriefing. From @cray_kate: https://t.co/cBPDTbRLRw

name: TheAtlantic
text: Even just delaying COVID-19 infections will save lives. @sarahzhang reports on falling death rates for hospitalized patients: https://t.co/sdzAJO08Vv

name: TheAtlantic
text: “It is unlikely to think that someone who was trained by Strom Thurmond would end up being like brothers with me, my father being a civil-rights activist.” @revdrbarber and @wilsonhartgrove tell @julieebeck how their friendship fuels their activism: https://t.co/AbKiN9YxLr

name: TheAtlantic
text: SPONSORED: Costumes from @Netflix's The Queen’s Gambit and @TheCrownNetflix will be paired with curated objects from the Brooklyn Museum's collection and you can experience the entire exhibit online here: https://t.co/Aw81mcguL5 #TheQueenandTheCrown https://t.co/Npp8eSXZNP

name: TheAtlantic
text: “I felt as though an ocular dial had been tweaked and the details of my life—objects, surfaces, textures—began to intensify.” Oliver Munday on how reading Proust during the pandemic sharpened his perception: https://t.co/JxAZ6JTaOZ

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @davidfrum: "We're not a democracy."

"If not, we should be."

Latest in @TheAtlantic https://t.co/fyRy0y1ACu

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @prashantrao: "We know that waiting for the end of something, anything, does not truly provide a fresh start, and certainly not a return to the way things were before." Make time to read @KimGhattas in @TheAtlantic https://t.co/qQlVBDJ0QU

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @davidfrum: After police attacks in Graham NC and MAGA attempt at running Biden bus off road in Texas - a piece on why Trump world is acting so manic. What's on the line in 2020 is a generation of political dominance. Latest in @TheAtlantic https://t.co/fyRy0y1ACu

name: TheAtlantic
text: "Anthem," a new poem by @theferocity: "Know that the sky has been grieving her ever since. / Know that the fire falling on us now began as grateful tears." https://t.co/vJK8LcQzOP

name: TheAtlantic
text: "Biden’s commitment to alliances and collective problem-solving would mark a return to a global framework that Trump has dismissed and sought to dismantle," Ryan Crocker writes. https://t.co/97Hqv6H5Jc

name: TheAtlantic
text: “All the signs are pointing to a high risk of violence right now,” one expert tells @olgakhazan. https://t.co/DIf51jFG2h

name: TheAtlantic
text: 1/ The 2020 election is close enough that you can feel its dragon breath on your neck. If you’re looking for an escape from unstructured doom-scrolling, we compiled six suggestions for how to kill time productively in our daily newsletter. https://t.co/X1XjyOWPCs

name: TheAtlantic
text:
2/ Adjust your expectations.

We may not know who the president is on Election Night. @bartongellman explained the myriad ways this election could break down, particularly if it’s close, in our November cover story: https://t.co/CA5zUS0eBp

name: TheAtlantic
text:
3/ Consider limiting your news consumption.

As @LoriGottlieb1 wrote in March: “Bingeing on up-to-the-minute news is like stress eating—it’s bloating our minds with unhealthy food that will make us feel sick.” https://t.co/MR6MEpgzpF

name: TheAtlantic
text:
4/ De-stress with an election-anxiety playlist.

Spencer Kornhaber, who writes about music, curated 12 songs to help you express impatience, agitation, and hope. https://t.co/vzPbgsl6pK

name: TheAtlantic
text:
5/ Kill time by streaming a political drama.

Our staff writer Hannah Giorgis recommends “Scandal,” “where any political nightmare can be solved as soon as Olivia Pope defiantly announces that ‘it’s handled.’” https://t.co/GoFND7jn9Z

name: TheAtlantic
text: 6/ Or read something totally unrelated to politics—like this thrilling longread about a renowned scholar, a piece of papyrus from the century in which Jesus is said to have lived, and the allegations of theft, cover-up, and fraud that followed. https://t.co/zHIbFyKU7t

name: TheAtlantic
text: 7/7 And subscribe to the newsletter here: https://t.co/nxKhpcaXAy

name: TheAtlantic
text: "Both versions of Reg are real—the one tolerant enough to see that we are worthy of raising his nephew, and the one who thinks people who hold our views are 'unhinged.'" @stevefriess on the Trump superfan who helped him and his husband adopt a son: https://t.co/3ZF9drnHe7

name: TheAtlantic
text: Over decades, and then very quickly, Lebanon lost so much. Things can never be as they were before. @KimGhattas writes of Beirut, and the lessons it holds for America: https://t.co/hvV08JMgTY

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @fhill_official: "Only dead light can understand what she did for us that night. Know that the sky has been grieving her ever since." this is such a beautiful and devastating poem from @theferocity https://t.co/aT9o2mgPi6

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @YAppelbaum: 1. In October 2008, John McCain knew he was losing. In a hotel room one night in La Crosse Wisconsin, his staff huddled around him, he took out a batter copy of Hemingway, and read aloud “The Snows of Kilimanjaro,” to its end: https://t.co/KH8kljBqUN

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @prashantrao: Even before the blast at Beirut's port, Lebanon had lost so much. To compare it to America may seem absurd, but @KimGhattas hits on so many worrying notes: https://t.co/qQlVBE0BIs

name: TheAtlantic
text: "The only major question left is whether the story relayed decades and even centuries from now will end with what Trump did to America or with what America did to Trump," @thomaswright08 writes: https://t.co/zhjqeR9wEa

name: TheAtlantic
text: There's plenty that's going wrong for Trump. Here are four things his campaign is doing now to close the gap with Joe Biden, @PeterAtlantic reports. https://t.co/Hfob1fQO4a

name: TheAtlantic
text: The Atlantic Daily: Will this decade be the new 1850s? https://t.co/j52p2oSnSw
